instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-2936: What is 820-2936? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> heating, "coreduetd" process using 100% process
threads.message:
Hello,
This machine had a dead keyboard, dead battery, but the board seems ok.
Test ASD144 is ok, but sometimes CPU temperatures are above 80º due to a "coreduetd" process using all the CPU time.
I found a solution on the net, namely:
[LIST=1]
[*]In the [B]Finder menu[/B] choose [B]Go[/B] -> [B]Go to Folder…[/B]
[*]Type: “[B]/var/db/coreduet[/B]”
[*][B]Delete everything[/B] in that folder
[*][B]Restart[/B]
[/LIST]
Nevertheless no explanation on the origin of this, and if it can appear again.

So I wonder if this is not hardware related? How can I trust the board if issues like this can happen at any moment?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> heating, "coreduetd" process using 100% process
threads.message:
Software problems must be discarded with new installation.
Sometimes need to test with other disk also.
You should have USB preinstalled macOS for test in service...
